name: Toida's conjecture
rephrased: A conjecture about the labeling of cubic graphs, refining Ádám's earlier conjecture which was disproven.
implication_form: If a graph satisfies certain conditions (not specified here), then it must be isomorphic to a specific type of cubic graph (not specified here).
explained: Toida's conjecture states that a tournament (a complete graph with directed edges) with an odd number of vertices has a cyclic rotational symmetry if and only if the number of vertices is a power of 2. In other words, such a tournament admits a cyclic group of automorphisms acting regularly (i.e., transitively and freely) if and only if the order of the tournament is a power of 2.
